Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Three-body Analysis in the Finite Volume
Award.AbstractNarration:
Strong forces are responsible for the formation of matter as we know it, but the detailed understanding of the underlying mechanism remains a challenge in the physics of hadrons, elementary particles most susceptible to the strong force. The origin of mass and the patterns of resonance phenomena within hadrons can be addressed in principle using ab-initio simulations of the strong force. Yet the connection between simulation data and the physical world represents a major conceptual problem. In this context, this project will develop and apply theoretical and computational methods intended to support the experimental program at the Jefferson National Accelerator Facility and close the gap between observed phenomena and their explanation from first principles. The PI will also develop a computer programming workshop for local high schools and will develop a course at the George Washington University to provide undergraduates with the skills necessary to analyze data in physics and other disciplines.

The underlying theory of the strong force, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), can be simulated using Lattice QCD methods on supercomputers. However, the small volumes probed in these calculations lead to numerical artefacts generally referred to as finite-volume effects. For the three particles case, these effects are not understood. As such, this project aims to develop three-body methods to enable the extrapolation of Lattice QCD results to the physical world and to help answer the fundamental question regarding the QCD predictions for the properties of excited mesons and baryons. The PI and his students will use the Faddeev formalism in the isobar approximation to addresses conceptual challenges such as three-body unitarity. Widely usable analysis tools, designed for minimal model dependence, will be developed and will be applied to the study of systems of high current interest, such as exotics, the X(3872), and the Roper resonance that exhibits notorious problems in QCD simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The strong force as one of the fundamental interactions of Nature provides the formation of matter as we know it. The theory of strong forces, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), can nowadays be solved on supercomputers, but only in a small volume (lattice QCD).

We provided the mapping from this small volume to Nature, i.e., the infinite volume, for systems of three excited particles. Such systems can form resonances which bear the key of our understanding of strong forces. In some of them, namely the exotics, a fundamental degree of freedom of QCD, the gluon, is manifestly present, which has motivated large experimental campaigns for their search, for example, at the Thomas Jefferson Accelerator Facility or CERN. Our research provides a connection between ab-initio lattice QCD calculations and experiment in this endeavor.

To achieve this connection, a framework was developed that is based on scattering theory, and, in particular, the principle of unitarity. As a highlight, the approach successfully predicted lattice QCD data of three pions at maximal isospin, both qualitatively and quantitatively. Patterns in the spectrum were deciphered to be manifestations of unitarity, and the approach was also extended to other hadronic systems, in connection with chiral extrapolations.

In summary, the approach has reached a maturity that allows to perform future caclulations of many different resonances of current interest.

The outreach component of the grant consisted in undergraduate research on statistics and computational physics. Also, a course on data analysis and statistics was developed that is now a recurring component of the graduate curriculum at The George Washington University.
